member.name: T:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.COM
member.summary: Provides COM (Component Object Model) methods from Ole32.dll.

member.name: M:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.COM.CoInitializeEx(FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.COM.CoInit)
member.summary: Initializes the COM library for use by the calling thread, sets the thread's concurrency model, and creates a new apartment for the thread if one is required.
member.param: The concurrency model and initialization options for the thread. Any combination of values from can be used, except that the and flags cannot both be set. The default is .
member.returns: This function can return either or .
member.remarks:
must be called at least once, and is usually called only once, for each thread that uses the COM library. Multiple calls to by the same thread are allowed as long as they pass the same concurrency flag, but subsequent valid calls return . If the concurrency flag does not match, then the call fails and returns . (For the purpose of this rule, a call to CoInitialize is equivalent to calling with the flag.) To uninitialize the COM library gracefully on a thread, each successful call to CoInitialize or , including any call that returns , must be balanced by a corresponding call to . Once COM has been uninitialized on a thread, you can reinitialize it in any mode, subject to the constraints above.
You need to initialize the COM library on a thread before you call any of the library functions except CoGetMalloc, to get a pointer to the standard allocator, and the memory allocation functions. Otherwise, the COM function will return .
Objects created in a single-threaded apartment (STA) receive method calls only from their apartment's thread, so calls are serialized and arrive only at message-queue boundaries (when the PeekMessage or SendMessage function is called).
Objects created on a COM thread in a multithread apartment (MTA) must be able to receive method calls from other threads at any time. You would typically implement some form of concurrency control in a multithreaded object's code using synchronization primitives such as critical sections, semaphores, or mutexes to help protect the object's data.
When an object that is configured to run in the neutral threaded apartment (NTA) is called by a thread that is in either an STA or the MTA, that thread transfers to the NTA. If this thread subsequently calls , the call fails and returns .
Because OLE technologies are not thread-safe, the OleInitialize function calls with the flag. As a result, an apartment that is initialized for multithreaded object concurrency cannot use the features enabled by OleInitialize.
Because there is no way to control the order in which in-process servers are loaded or unloaded, do not call CoInitialize, , or from the DllMain function.

member.name: M:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.COM.CoUninitialize
member.summary: Closes the COM library on the current thread, unloads all DLLs loaded by the thread, frees any other resources that the thread maintains, and forces all RPC connections on the thread to close.
member.remarks:
A thread must call once for each successful call it has made to the CoInitialize or function, including any call that returns S_FALSE. Only the call corresponding to the CoInitialize or call that initialized the library can close it.
Calls to OleInitialize must be balanced by calls to OleUninitialize. The OleUninitialize function calls internally, so applications that call OleUninitialize do not also need to call .
should be called on application shutdown, as the last call made to the COM library after the application hides its main windows and falls through its main message loop. If there are open conversations remaining, starts a modal message loop and dispatches any pending messages from the containers or server for this COM application. By dispatching the messages, ensures that the application does not quit before receiving all of its pending messages. Non-COM messages are discarded.
Because there is no way to control the order in which in-process servers are loaded or unloaded, do not call CoInitialize, , or from the DllMain function.

member.name: T:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.COM.CoInit
member.summary: Specifies flags for .

remarks.para: When a thread is initialized through a call to , you choose whether to initialize it as apartment-threaded or multithreaded by designating one of the members of as its parameter. This designates how incoming calls to any object created by that thread are handled, that is, the object's concurrency.

Apartment-threading, while allowing for multiple threads of execution, serializes all incoming calls by requiring that calls to methods of objects created by this thread always run on the same thread, i.e. the apartment/thread that created them. In addition, calls can arrive only at message-queue boundaries. Because of this serialization, it is not typically necessary to write concurrency control into the code for the object, other than to avoid calls to PeekMessage and during processing that must not be interrupted by other method invocations or calls to other objects in the same apartment/thread.

Multi-threading (also called free-threading) allows calls to methods of objects created by this thread to be run on any thread. There is no serialization of calls, i.e. many calls may occur to the same method or to the same object or simultaneously. Multi-threaded object concurrency offers the highest performance and takes the best advantage of multiprocessor hardware for cross-thread, cross-process, and cross-machine calling, since calls to objects are not serialized in any way.This means, however, that the code for objects must enforce its own concurrency model, typically through the use of synchronization primitives, such as critical sections, semaphores, or mutexes. In addition, because the object doesn't control the lifetime of the threads that are accessing it, no thread-specific state may be stored in the object (in Thread Local Storage).
remarks.i: Note: The multi-threaded apartment is intended for use by non-GUI threads. Threads in multi-threaded apartments should not perform UI actions. This is because UI threads require a message pump, and COM does not pump messages for threads in a multi-threaded apartment.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_DRM_ACQUIRING_LICENSE
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot download additional media usage rights until the current download is complete.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_DRM_LICENSE_EXPIRED
member.summary: The media usage rights for this file have expired or are no longer valid. If you obtained the file from an online store, sign in to the store, and then try again.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_DRM_LICENSE_NOTACQUIRED
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot download the media usage rights for the file. If you obtained the file from an online store, sign in to the store, and then try again.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_DRM_LICENSE_NOTENABLED
member.summary: The media usage rights for this file are not yet valid. To see when they will become valid, right-click the file in the library, click Properties, and then click the Media Usage Rights tab.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_DRM_LICENSE_UNUSABLE
member.summary: The media usage rights for this file are not valid. If you obtained this file from an online store, contact the store for assistance.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_DRM_LICENSE_CONTENT_REVOKED
member.summary: The content provider has revoked the media usage rights for this file. If you obtained this file from an online store, ask the store if a new version of the file is available.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_DRM_LICENSE_NOSAP
member.summary: The media usage rights for this file require a feature that is not supported in your current version of Windows Media Player or your current version of Windows. Try installing the latest version of the Player. If you obtained this file from an online store, contact the store for further assistance.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_DRM_UNABLE_TO_ACQUIRE_LICENSE
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot download media usage rights at this time. Try again later.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_LICENSE_REQUIRED
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot play, burn, or sync the file because the media usage rights are missing. If you obtained the file from an online store, sign in to the store, and then try again.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_PROTECTED_CONTENT
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot play, burn, or sync the file because the media usage rights are missing. If you obtained the file from an online store, sign in to the store, and then try again.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_WMP_POLICY_VALUE_NOT_CONFIGURED
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot read a policy. This can occur when the policy does not exist in the registry or when the registry cannot be read.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_CANNOT_SYNC_FROM_INTERNET
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot sync content streamed directly from the Internet. If possible, download the file to your computer, and then try to sync the file.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_CANNOT_SYNC_INVALID_PLAYLIST
member.summary: This playlist is not valid or is corrupted. Create a new playlist using Windows Media Player, then sync the new playlist instead.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_FAILED_TO_SYNCHRONIZE_FILE
member.summary: Windows Media Player encountered a problem while synchronizing the file to the device. For additional assistance, click Web Help.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_SYNC_FAILED
member.summary: Windows Media Player encountered an error while synchronizing to the device.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_DELETE_FAILED
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot delete a file from the device.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_FAILED_TO_RETRIEVE_FILE
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot copy a file from the device to your library.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_DEVICE_NOT_RESPONDING
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot communicate with the device because the device is not responding. Try reconnecting the device, resetting the device, or contacting the device manufacturer for updated firmware.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_FAILED_TO_TRANSCODE_PHOTO
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot sync the picture to the device because a problem occurred while converting the file to another quality level or format. The original file might be damaged or corrupted.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_FAILED_TO_ENCRYPT_TRANSCODED_FILE
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot convert the file. The file might have been encrypted by the Encrypted File System (EFS). Try decrypting the file first and then synchronizing it. For information about how to decrypt a file, see Windows Help and Support.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_CANNOT_TRANSCODE_TO_AUDIO
member.summary: Your device requires that this file be converted in order to play on the device. However, the device either does not support playing audio, or Windows Media Player cannot convert the file to an audio format that is supported by the device.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_CANNOT_TRANSCODE_TO_VIDEO
member.summary: Your device requires that this file be converted in order to play on the device. However, the device either does not support playing video, or Windows Media Player cannot convert the file to a video format that is supported by the device.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_CANNOT_TRANSCODE_TO_IMAGE
member.summary: Your device requires that this file be converted in order to play on the device. However, the device either does not support displaying pictures, or Windows Media Player cannot convert the file to a picture format that is supported by the device.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_RETRIEVED_FILE_FILENAME_TOO_LONG
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot sync the file to your computer because the file name is too long. Try renaming the file on the device.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_PDA_CEWMDM_DRM_ERROR
member.summary: Windows Media Player cannot sync the file because the device is not responding. This typically occurs when there is a problem with the device firmware. For additional assistance, click Web Help.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.NS_E_INCOMPLETE_PLAYLIST
member.summary: Incomplete playlist.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_OPM_HDCP_SRM_NEVER_SET

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_OPM_ALL_HDCP_HARDWARE_ALREADY_IN_USE
member.summary: IOPMVideoOutput's Configure() method cannot enable HDCP because the display adapter's HDCP hardware is already being used by other physical outputs.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_OPM_VIDEO_OUTPUT_NO_LONGER_EXISTS
member.summary: The operating system asynchronously destroyed this OPM video output because the operating system's state changed. This error typically occurs because the monitor physical device object (PDO) associated with this video output was removed, the monitor PDO associated with this video output was stopped, the video output's session became a nonconsole session or the video output's desktop became an inactive desktop.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_OPM_SESSION_TYPE_CHANGE_IN_PROGRESS
member.summary: IOPMVideoOutput's methods cannot be called when a session is changing its type. There are currently three types of sessions: console, disconnected and remote (remote desktop protocol [RDP] or Independent Computing Architecture [ICA]).

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_I2C_NOT_SUPPORTED
member.summary: The monitor connected to the specified video output does not have an I2C bus.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_I2C_DEVICE_DOES_NOT_EXIST
member.summary: No device on the I2C bus has the specified address.

member.summary: An error occurred while transmitting data to the device on the I2C bus.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_I2C_ERROR_RECEIVING_DATA
member.summary: An error occurred while receiving data from the device on the I2C bus.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_DDCCI_MONITOR_RETURNED_INVALID_TIMING_STATUS_BYTE
member.summary: A function call failed because a monitor returned an invalid Timing Status byte when the operating system used the Display Data Channel Command Interface (DDC/CI) Get Timing Report and Timing Message command to get a timing report from a monitor.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_MCA_INVALID_CAPABILITIES_STRING
member.summary: The monitor returned a DDC/CI capabilities string that did not comply with the ACCESS.bus 3.0, DDC/CI 1.1 or MCCS 2 Revision 1 specification.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_MCA_INTERNAL_ERROR
member.summary: An internal Monitor Configuration API error occurred.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_DDCCI_INVALID_MESSAGE_COMMAND
member.summary: An operation failed because a DDC/CI message had an invalid value in its command field.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_DDCCI_INVALID_MESSAGE_LENGTH
member.summary: This error occurred because a DDC/CI message length field contained an invalid value.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_DDCCI_INVALID_MESSAGE_CHECKSUM
member.summary: This error occurred because the value in a DDC/CI message checksum field did not match the message's computed checksum value. This error implies that the data was corrupted while it was being transmitted from a monitor to a computer.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_PMEA_INVALID_MONITOR
member.summary: The HMONITOR no longer exists, is not attached to the desktop, or corresponds to a mirroring device.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_PMEA_INVALID_D3D_DEVICE
member.summary: The Direct3D (D3D) device's GDI display device no longer exists, is not attached to the desktop, or is a mirroring display device.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_DDCCI_CURRENT_CURRENT_VALUE_GREATER_THAN_MAXIMUM_VALUE
member.summary: A continuous VCP code's current value is greater than its maximum value. This error code indicates that a monitor returned an invalid value.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_MCA_INVALID_VCP_VERSION
member.summary: The monitor's VCP Version (0xDF) VCP code returned an invalid version value.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_MCA_MONITOR_VIOLATES_MCCS_SPECIFICATION
member.summary: The monitor does not comply with the Monitor Control Command Set (MCCS) specification it claims to support.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_MCA_MCCS_VERSION_MISMATCH
member.summary: The MCCS version in a monitor's mccs_ver capability does not match the MCCS version the monitor reports when the VCP Version (0xDF) VCP code is used.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_MCA_UNSUPPORTED_MCCS_VERSION
member.summary: The Monitor Configuration API only works with monitors that support the MCCS 1.0 specification, the MCCS 2.0 specification, or the MCCS 2.0 Revision 1 specification.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_MCA_INVALID_TECHNOLOGY_TYPE_RETURNED
member.summary: The monitor returned an invalid monitor technology type. CRT, plasma, and LCD (TFT) are examples of monitor technology types. This error implies that the monitor violated the MCCS 2.0 or MCCS 2.0 Revision 1 specification.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_MCA_UNSUPPORTED_COLOR_TEMPERATURE
member.summary: The SetMonitorColorTemperature() caller passed a color temperature to it that the current monitor did not support. CRT, plasma, and LCD (TFT) are examples of monitor technology types. This error implies that the monitor violated the MCCS 2.0 or MCCS 2.0 Revision 1 specification.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.HRESULT.ERROR_GRAPHICS_ONLY_CONSOLE_SESSION_SUPPORTED
member.summary: This function can be used only if a program is running in the local console session. It cannot be used if the program is running on a remote desktop session or on aterminal serversession.

member.name: M:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.ShellAbout(System.IntPtr,System.String,System.String,System.Drawing.Icon)
member.summary: Displays a ShellAbout dialog box. For an example of this dialog box, run the winver command.
member.example: For an example of this dialog box, run the winver command.
member.param: A window handle to a parent window.

A string that contains text to be displayed in the title bar of the ShellAbout dialog box and on the first line of the dialog box after the text "Microsoft". If the text contains a separator (#) that divides it into two parts, the function displays the first part in the title bar and the second part on the first line after the text "Microsoft".
Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008: This string cannot exceed 200 characters in length. The contents of will no longer show after "Microsoft", unless there is a # separator, in which case the part after the # will completely replace the first line.
A string that contains text to be displayed in the dialog box after the version and copyright information. This parameter can be .
An icon that is displayed in the dialog box. This parameter can be , in which case the dialog displays the Windows icon.

member.name: T:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHFILEINFO
member.summary: The internal Windows API struct for . Use with .

member.name: M:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.DestroyIcon(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Destroys an icon and frees any memory the icon occupied.
member.param: A handle to the icon to be destroyed. The icon must not be in use.
member.returns: if successful; otherwise, . To get extended error information, call .

remarks.para: It is only necessary to call for icons and cursors created with the following functions: CreateIconFromResourceEx (if called without the LR_SHARED flag), CreateIconIndirect, and CopyIcon. Do not use this function to destroy a shared icon. A shared icon is valid as long as the module from which it was loaded remains in memory. The following functions obtain a shared icon:

item.description: LoadImage (if you use the LR_SHARED flag)
CopyImage (if you use the LR_COPYRETURNORG flag and the hImage parameter is a shared icon)
CreateIconFromResourceEx (if you use the LR_SHARED flag)

member.name: T:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags
member.summary: Provides flags for the Windows API function . To use this function, call the wrapper instead.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_ADDOVERLAYS
member.summary: Version 5.0. Apply the appropriate overlays to the file's icon. The SHGFI_ICON flag must also be set.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_ATTR_SPECIFIED
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ATTRIBUTES to indicate that the dwAttributes member of the SHFILEINFO structure at psfi contains the specific attributes that are desired. These attributes are passed to IShellFolder::GetAttributesOf. If this flag is not specified, 0xFFFFFFFF is passed to IShellFolder::GetAttributesOf, requesting all attributes. This flag cannot be specified with the SHGFI_ICON flag.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_ATTRIBUTES
member.summary: Retrieve the item attributes. The attributes are copied to the dwAttributes member of the structure specified in the psfi parameter. These are the same attributes that are obtained from IShellFolder::GetAttributesOf.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_DISPLAYNAME
member.summary: Retrieve the display name for the file, which is the name as it appears in Windows Explorer. The name is copied to the szDisplayName member of the structure specified in psfi. The returned display name uses the long file name, if there is one, rather than the 8.3 form of the file name. Note that the display name can be affected by settings such as whether extensions are shown.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_EXETYPE
member.summary: Retrieve the type of the executable file if pszPath identifies an executable file. The information is packed into the return value. This flag cannot be specified with any other flags.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_ICON
member.summary: Retrieve the handle to the icon that represents the file and the index of the icon within the system image list. The handle is copied to the hIcon member of the structure specified by psfi, and the index is copied to the iIcon member.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_ICONLOCATION
member.summary: Retrieve the name of the file that contains the icon representing the file specified by pszPath, as returned by the IExtractIcon::GetIconLocation method of the file's icon handler. Also retrieve the icon index within that file. The name of the file containing the icon is copied to the szDisplayName member of the structure specified by psfi. The icon's index is copied to that structure's iIcon member.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_LARGEICON
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to retrieve the file's large icon. The SHGFI_ICON flag must also be set.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_LINKOVERLAY
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to add the link overlay to the file's icon. The SHGFI_ICON flag must also be set.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_OPENICON
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to retrieve the file's open icon. Also used to modify SHGFI_SYSICONINDEX, causing the function to return the handle to the system image list that contains the file's small open icon. A container object displays an open icon to indicate that the container is open. The SHGFI_ICON and/or SHGFI_SYSICONINDEX flag must also be set.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_OVERLAYINDEX
member.summary: Version 5.0. Return the index of the overlay icon. The value of the overlay index is returned in the upper eight bits of the iIcon member of the structure specified by psfi. This flag requires that the SHGFI_ICON be set as well.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_PIDL
member.summary: Indicate that pszPath is the address of an ITEMIDLIST structure rather than a path name.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_SELECTED
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to blend the file's icon with the system highlight color. The SHGFI_ICON flag must also be set.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_SHELLICONSIZE
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to retrieve a Shell-sized icon. If this flag is not specified the function sizes the icon according to the system metric values. The SHGFI_ICON flag must also be set.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_SMALLICON
member.summary: Modify SHGFI_ICON, causing the function to retrieve the file's small icon. Also used to modify SHGFI_SYSICONINDEX, causing the function to return the handle to the system image list that contains small icon images. The SHGFI_ICON and/or SHGFI_SYSICONINDEX flag must also be set.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_SYSICONINDEX
member.summary: Retrieve the index of a system image list icon. If successful, the index is copied to the iIcon member of psfi. The return value is a handle to the system image list. Only those images whose indices are successfully copied to iIcon are valid. Attempting to access other images in the system image list will result in undefined behavior.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_TYPENAME
member.summary: Retrieve the string that describes the file's type. The string is copied to the szTypeName member of the structure specified in psfi.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags.SHGFI_USEFILEATTRIBUTES
member.summary: Indicates that the function should not attempt to access the file specified by pszPath. Rather, it should act as if the file specified by pszPath exists with the file attributes passed in dwFileAttributes. This flag cannot be combined with the SHGFI_ATTRIBUTES, SHGFI_EXETYPE, or SHGFI_PIDL flags.

member.name: M:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.GetFileInfo(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves information about an object in the file system, such as a file, folder, directory, or drive root.
member.param:
A string of maximum length that contains the path and file name. Both absolute and relative paths are valid.
This string can use either short (the 8.3 form) or long file names.
member.returns: The instance containing the data about the file if successful; otherwise, .

member.name: M:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.GetFileInfoEx(System.String,FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes,FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHGetFileInfoFlags,FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.Shell32.SHFILEINFO@)
member.summary: Retrieves information about an object in the file system, such as a file, folder, directory, or drive root. This function provides all the customization of the Windows API function , unlike .
member.param:
A string of maximum length that contains the path and file name. Both absolute and relative paths are valid.
If the parameter includes the flag, this parameter must be the address of an ITEMIDLIST(PIDL) structure that contains the list of item identifiers that uniquely identifies the file within the Shell's namespace. The PIDL must be a fully qualified PIDL. Relative PIDLs are not allowed.
If the parameter includes the flag, this parameter does not have to be a valid file name. The function will proceed as if the file exists with the specified name and with the file attributes passed in the dwFileAttributes parameter. This allows you to obtain information about a file type by passing just the extension for pszPath and passing FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NORMAL in dwFileAttributes.
This string can use either short (the 8.3 form) or long file names.
A combination of one or more file attribute flags ( values). If does not include the flag, this parameter is ignored, so in that case you should set it to instead.
The flags that specify the file information to retrieve. This should be a combination of values.
Pointer to a structure to receive the file information.
member.returns:
A value whose meaning depends on the parameter.
If does not contain or , the return value is non-zero if successful, or zero otherwise.
If contains the flag, the return value specifies the type of the executable file. It will be one of the following values:
0 Nonexecutable file or an error condition.
LOWORD = NE or PE and HIWORD = Windows version Windows application.
LOWORD = PE and HIWORD = 0 Console application or .bat file
member.remarks:
You should call this function from a background thread. Failure to do so could cause the UI to stop responding.
If returns an icon handle in the member of the structure pointed to by , you are responsible for freeing it with when you no longer need it. The wrapper automatically cleans up these resources on dispose, so you should ideally use and convert to a using the constructor. Additionaly, provides managed types for almost all the properties, so using it is preffered.
Note: Once you have a handle to a system image list, you can use the Image List API to manipulate it like any other image list. Because system image lists are created on a per-process basis, you should treat them as read-only objects. Writing to a system image list may overwrite or delete one of the system images, making it unavailable or incorrect for the remainder of the process.
You must initialize Component Object Model (COM) with prior to calling . wraps this automatically.
When you use the flag with a Windows application, the Windows version of the executable is given in the HIWORD of the return value. This version is returned as a hexadecimal value. For details on equating this value with a specific Windows version, see Using the Windows Headers.

member.summary: Displays a merged property sheet for a set of files. Property values common to all the files are shown, while those that differ display the string (multiple values).
member.param: The file paths of the files to show.
member.returns: If this function succeeds, it returns . Otherwise, it returns a error code.

member.name: T:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes
member.summary: Specifies attributes for Windows files.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.None
member.summary: A file that does not have other attributes set. This attribute is valid only when used alone. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NORMAL)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.ReadOnly
member.summary: A file that is read-only. Applications can read the file, but cannot write to it or delete it. This attribute is not honored on directories. For more information, see You cannot view or change the Read-only or the System attributes of folders in Windows Server 2003, in Windows XP, in Windows Vista or in Windows 7. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_READONLY)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Hidden
member.summary: The file or directory is hidden. It is not included in an ordinary directory listing. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_HIDDEN)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.System
member.summary: A file or directory that the operating system uses as part of, or uses exclusively. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_SYSTEM)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Directory
member.summary: The handle that identifies a directory. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_DIRECTORY)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Archive
member.summary: A file or directory that is an archive file or directory. Applications typically use this attribute to mark files for backup or removal. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ARCHIVE)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Device
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use. Do not use. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_DEVICE)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Temporary
member.summary: A file that is being used for temporary storage. File systems avoid writing data back to mass storage if sufficient cache memory is available, because typically, an application deletes a temporary file after the handle is closed. In that scenario, the system can entirely avoid writing the data. Otherwise, the data is written after the handle is closed. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_TEMPORARY)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Sparse
member.summary: A file that is a sparse file. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_SPARSE_FILE)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.ReparsePoint
member.summary: A file or directory that has an associated reparse point, or a file that is a symbolic link.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Compressed
member.summary: A file or directory that is compressed. For a file, all of the data in the file is compressed. For a directory, compression is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Offline
member.summary: The data of a file is not available immediately. This attribute indicates that the file data is physically moved to offline storage. This attribute is used by Remote Storage, which is the hierarchical storage management software. Applications should not arbitrarily change this attribute. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_OFFLINE)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.NoContentIndex
member.summary: The file or directory is not to be indexed by the content indexing service. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NOT_CONTENT_INDEXED)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Encrypted
member.summary: A file or directory that is encrypted. For a file, all data streams in the file are encrypted. For a directory, encryption is the default for newly created files and subdirectories. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ENCRYPTED)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.IntegrityStream
member.summary: The directory or user data stream is configured with integrity (only supported on ReFS volumes). It is not included in an ordinary directory listing. The integrity setting persists with the file if it's renamed. If a file is copied the destination file will have integrity set if either the source file or destination directory have integrity set. Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This flag is not supported until Windows Server 2012. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_INTEGRITY_STREAM)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Virtual
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use. Do not use. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_VIRTUAL)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.NoScrubData
member.summary: The user data stream not to be read by the background data integrity scanner (AKA scrubber). When set on a directory it only provides inheritance. This flag is only supported on Storage Spaces and ReFS volumes. It is not included in an ordinary directory listing. Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This flag is not supported until Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NO_SCRUB_DATA)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.ExAttrib
member.summary: A file or directory with extended attributes. This value is for internal use only. Do not use. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_EA)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Pinned
member.summary: This attribute indicates user intent that the file or directory should be kept fully present locally even when not being actively accessed. This attribute is for use with hierarchical storage management software. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_PINNED)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.Unpinned
member.summary: This attribute indicates that the file or directory should not be kept fully present locally except when being actively accessed. This attribute is for use with hierarchical storage management software. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_UNPINNED)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.RecallOnOpen
member.summary: This attribute only appears in directory enumeration classes (FILE_DIRECTORY_INFORMATION, FILE_BOTH_DIR_INFORMATION, etc.). When this attribute is set, it means that the file or directory has no physical representation on the local system; the item is virtual. Opening the item will be more expensive than normal, e.g. it will cause at least some of it to be fetched from a remote store. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_RECALL_ON_OPEN)

member.name: F:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.WindowsFileAttributes.RecallOnDataAccess
member.summary: When this attribute is set, it means that the file or directory is not fully present locally. For a file that means that not all of its data is on local storage (e.g. it may be sparse with some data still in remote storage). For a directory it means that some of the directory contents are being virtualized from another location. Reading the file / enumerating the directory will be more expensive than normal, e.g. it will cause at least some of the file/directory content to be fetched from a remote store. Only kernel-mode callers can set this bit. File system mini filters below the 180000 – 189999 altitude range (FSFilter HSM Load Order Group) must not issue targeted cached reads or writes to files that have this attribute set. This could lead to cache pollution and potential file corruption. For more information, see Handling placeholders. (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_RECALL_ON_DATA_ACCESS)

member.name: M:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.User32.SetWindowLongPtr(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Changes an attribute of the specified window. The function also sets a value at the specified offset in the extra window memory.
member.param: A handle to the window and, indirectly, the class to which the window belongs. The function fails if the process that owns the window specified by the parameter is at a higher process privilege in the UIPI hierarchy than the process the calling thread resides in. Windows XP/2000: The function fails if the window specified by the hWnd parameter does not belong to the same process as the calling thread.

The zero-based offset to the value to be set. Valid values are in the range zero through the number of bytes of extra window memory, minus the size of a LONG_PTR. To set any other value, specify one of the .
The replacement value.
member.returns:
If the function succeeds, the return value is the previous value of the specified offset.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call .
If the previous value is zero and the function succeeds, the return value is zero, but the function does not clear the last error information. To determine success or failure, clear the last error information by calling SetLastError with 0, then call . Function failure will be indicated by a return value of zero and a result that is nonzero.
member.remarks:
Certain window data is cached, so changes you make using will not take effect until you call the SetWindowPos function.
If you use with the index to replace the window procedure, the window procedure must conform to the guidelines specified in the description of the WndProc callback function.
If you use with the index to set the return value for a message processed by a dialog box procedure, the dialog box procedure should return directly afterward. Otherwise, if you call any function that results in your dialog box procedure receiving a window message, the nested window message could overwrite the return value you set by using .
Calling with the index creates a subclass of the window class used to create the window. An application can subclass a system class, but should not subclass a window class created by another process.The function creates the window subclass by changing the window procedure associated with a particular window class, causing the system to call the new window procedure instead of the previous one.
Do not call with the index to change the parent of a child window. Instead, use the SetParent function. is used to change the owner of a top-level window, not the parent of a child window. A window can have either a parent or an owner, or neither, but never both simultaneously.
Calling to set the style on a progress bar will reset its position.

member.name: M:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.User32.GetWindowLongPtr(System.IntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves information about the specified window. The function also retrieves the value at a specified offset into the extra window memory.
member.param: A handle to the window and, indirectly, the class to which the window belongs.

The zero-based offset to the value to be retrieved. Valid values are in the range zero through the number of bytes of extra window memory, minus the size of a LONG_PTR. To retrieve any other value, specify one of the .
member.returns:
If the function succeeds, the return value is the requested value.
If the function fails, the return value is zero.To get extended error information, call .
If has not been called previously, returns zero for values in the extra window or class memory.
member.remarks: Reserve extra window memory by specifying a nonzero value in the cbWndExtra member of the WNDCLASSEX structure used with the RegisterClassEx function. Note: The winuser.h header defines as an alias that automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that is not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

member.name: M:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.User32.SendMessage(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.UIntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary:
Sends the specified message to a window or windows. The function calls the window procedure for the specified window and does not return until the window procedure has processed the message.
To send a message and return immediately, use the SendMessageCallback or SendNotifyMessage function. To post a message to a thread's message queue and return immediately, use the PostMessage or PostThreadMessage function.
member.param:
A handle to the window whose window procedure will receive the message. If this parameter is HWND_BROADCAST ((HWND)0xffff), the message is sent to all top-level windows in the system, including disabled or invisible unowned windows, overlapped windows, and pop-up windows; but the message is not sent to child windows.
Message sending is subject to UIPI. The thread of a process can send messages only to message queues of threads in processes of lesser or equal integrity level.

The message to be sent.
For lists of the system-provided messages, see System-Defined Messages.
Additional message-specific information.
Additional message-specific information.
member.returns: The return value specifies the result of the message processing; it depends on the message sent.
member.remarks:
When a message is blocked by UIPI the last error, retrieved with , is set to 5 (access denied).
Applications that need to communicate using HWND_BROADCAST should use the RegisterWindowMessage function to obtain a unique message for inter-application communication.
The system only does marshalling for system messages (those in the range 0 to (WM_USER-1)). To send other messages (those >= WM_USER) to another process, you must do custom marshalling.
If the specified window was created by the calling thread, the window procedure is called immediately as a subroutine. If the specified window was created by a different thread, the system switches to that thread and calls the appropriate window procedure. Messages sent between threads are processed only when the receiving thread executes message retrieval code.The sending thread is blocked until the receiving thread processes the message. However, the sending thread will process incoming nonqueued messages while waiting for its message to be processed. To prevent this, use SendMessageTimeout with SMTO_BLOCK set. For more information on non-queued messages, see Messages and Message Queues.
An accessibility application can use to send WM_APPCOMMAND messages to the shell to launch applications. This functionality is not guaranteed to work for other types of applications.

member.name: M:FireBlade.WinInteropUtils.User32.IsGUIThread(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Determines whether the calling thread is already a GUI thread. It can also optionally convert the thread to a GUI thread ().
member.param: If and the thread is not a GUI thread, convert the thread to a GUI thread.
member.returns:
The function returns a nonzero value in the following situations:
- If the calling thread is already a GUI thread.
- If is and the function successfully converts the thread to a GUI thread. Otherwise, the function returns zero. If is and the function cannot successfully convert the thread to a GUI thread, IsGUIThread returns ERROR_NOT_ENOUGH_MEMORY.
